oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Scene of night action on December 23, 1814
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Black and white engraving, "Night Action of the Twenty-third of December," shows American infantry marching, cannoneers firing an artillery piece, and a commander (probably General Andrew Jackson) on horseback. Decorative border includes a flag and musket resting on a cannon. Border is topped with an American eagle perched upon two flags. From John Frost and W. Croome, Pictorial Life of Andrew Jackson.

The Battle of New Orleans was a series of clashes for control of the city with combat taking place between December 1814 and January 1815. General Andrew Jackson commanded an American force that overwhelmed the British enemy on January 8, 1815. Because of slow transatlantic communications, neither side was aware that a peace treaty had been signed two weeks earlier.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Campaigns & battles; Arms & armament; Soldiers; Horses
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Baker, S. F.
